commit_message:
Update helm-toolkit db-init script and manifest
for both mysql and postgresql

  * Add the ability to create a mysql user with specific
    permission on specific table
  * Add the ability to create a postgres user with specific
    permission on specific table

Change-Id: I081c0d21e12206ec2cd39f7b08e4fabbbc63b421

commit_message:
CentOS 8: Add deploy jobs in CI

Adds the following deploy jobs, defined in kolla-ansible, to the CI
check pipeline:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source
- kolla-ansible-centos8-binary
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-cinder-lvm
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-scenario-nfv
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ironic

The following job is not yet passing:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-bifrost

Also adds the following deploy job to the CI gate pipeline:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source

Partially-Implements: blueprint centos-rhel-8

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/693544/

Change-Id: Idca0f983451fb67527f4917642de510dbf9af921

commit_message:
Bump molecule version

- Use latest version of molecule
- Remove lint config as we do it using tox-linters
- Adopts newer converge playbook name to avoid deprecation warning

Change-Id: Ica6b57932b288dae547b4e78e297665d083d8825

subject: Change the default multicast group range
messages:
[{'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-02-05 11:26:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2020-02-05 16:11:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-02-06 14:37:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

the change is fine for me but I don't understand one thing. Even with this change this multicast test is passing but enable_igmp_snooping config option is set to false by default in neutron-ovs-agent so igmp snooping isn't enabled on br-int. So how those packets are delivered to the instances than? Do You know what am I missing there?"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:12:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> the change is fine for me but I don't understand one thing. Even
 > with this change this multicast test is passing but
 > enable_igmp_snooping config option is set to false by default in
 > neutron-ovs-agent so igmp snooping isn't enabled on br-int. So how
 > those packets are delivered to the instances than? Do You know what
 > am I missing there?

So we spoke on IRC but the summary (of our understand, and confirmed by dceara) is:

1. igmp snooping enabled -> flooding 224 traffic and not flooding everything else

2. if igmp snooping disabled -> flooding all multicast"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-02-07 09:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-02-07 14:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2020-02-07 16:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-05 11:26:28.000000000', 'message': 'Change the default multicast group range

The 224.0.0.X range is a special range in multicast which acts like a
broadcast for non-IGMP traffic.

This patch changes the value of the multicast_group_range configuration
option to 225.0.0.X to avoid this special case.

See session "2.1.2.  Data Forwarding Rules" at
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4541 for more information:

   2) Packets with a destination IP (DIP) address in the 224.0.0.X range
         which are not IGMP must be forwarded on all ports.

Change-Id: Ic8fd860fa7ad6b5401297254e56a796c98bb037a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Change the default multicast group range

The 224.0.0.X range is a special range in multicast which acts like a
broadcast for non-IGMP traffic.

This patch changes the value of the multicast_group_range configuration
option to 225.0.0.X to avoid this special case.

See session "2.1.2.  Data Forwarding Rules" at
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4541 for more information:

   2) Packets with a destination IP (DIP) address in the 224.0.0.X range
         which are not IGMP must be forwarded on all ports.

Change-Id: Ic8fd860fa7ad6b5401297254e56a796c98bb037a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Remove mistral from the set_deployment_status* workflows

This change removes the mistral workflows from our set_deployment_status
function, which called three different mistral workflows.

- set_deployment_status_success
- set_deployment_status_failed
- set_deployment_status_deploying

Task: 38660
Story: 2007212

Change-Id: Idc18c245dc9debcf5236170e0aa99277e58d68a3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix test_connectivity_dvr_and_no_dvr_routers_in_same_subnet test

This patch fixes couple of issues in scenario test from
test_connectivity module.

1. Replace safe_client with client object
   In class NetworkConnectivityTest there was used safe_client
   but there is no such attribute in this class. Object "client"
   should be used instead.

2. It also fixes in the same test how external network's subnet
   ID is get from the network's info.

3. Change to use admin_client to get details of external
   network's subnet as this subnet don't belongs to tenant user
   so regular client gets 404 error while doing subnet_show
   command.

4. Check the subnets IP version to retrieve only an IPv4 one.

Change-Id: Ibebb20b29dd6ae902d194fd26ba1ea728a976286
Closes-bug: #1861670

commit_message:
Remove mistral from the discover_and_enroll workflow

This change removes mistral from the discover_and_enroll workflow by managing the
context and simply calling the required methods. This change will speed up the
general execution process and ensure better reliability as we'll no longer require
mistral or zaqar to execute this workflow.

Story: 2007212
Task: 38450

Change-Id: Ic13a3f70383afdc23abd29b8db230f01e0bebf55
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Setup registry only when containers are locally pushed

This patch also does following:-
- Bring buildah setup out of docker setup block
  as buildah can be setup without docker being setup.
- Use host ip instead of docker bridge ip as setting
  up docker is optional.
- Setup docker only for rhel < 8 as docker is not available
  since rhel8.

Change-Id: Icfbe77fa6e21754cfc62462ec4e379f61034400c

commit_message:
Remove mistral from the get_deployment_status workflow

This change Converts plan status checks to using a direct call instead of
executing via mistral.

* A new method was added allowing us to update the deployment status object
  when required.
* Tests have been added for the new static method update_deployment_status.

Story: 2007212
Task: 38430

Change-Id: Ie19be2078e2f349bf06e5b99ab93ca843e367463
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

work as expected. The current change should allow a better readability
of the check task.

commit_message:
Remove deprecated authtoken::auth_uri

auth_uri parameter in authtoken was already removed from puppet modules[1],
so remove it from hieradata.

Also, some service templates missed www_authenticate_uri, which was
introduced as a replacement of auth_uri, so add it to make sure that
we have a correct parameter confugured.

[1] I12b4049e4942911c8d1d8027c579eb4c0d1a53eb

Change-Id: I1e8378f58662377344194916e8bc336df02d0591

commit_message:
CentOS 8: Add deploy jobs in CI

Adds new CI job definitions for CentOS 8:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source
- kolla-ansible-centos8-binary
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ceph-ansible
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-cinder-lvm
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-mariadb
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-bifrost
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-zun
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-swift
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-scenario-nfv
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ironic
- kolla-ansible-centos8-binary-ironic
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-masakari
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-cells

The following jobs are added to the check pipeline:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source
- kolla-ansible-centos8-binary
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-cinder-lvm
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-mariadb
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-zun
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-swift
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-scenario-nfv
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ironic
- kolla-ansible-centos8-binary-ironic
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-cells

The following jobs are not yet passing so are not added to the check
pipeline:

- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ceph-ansible
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-bifrost
- kolla-ansible-centos8-source-masakari

The kolla-ansible-centos8-source job is added to the gate.

Upgrade jobs will be added when CentOS 8 support exists in Train.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704337
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704848
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704965

Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>

Change-Id: Ibd806feee71721b122b77d7eff33228ca1cc2853
Partially-Implements: blueprint centos-rhel-8

commit_message:
Generate self signed TLS certificates

Generate both internal and external self signed TLS certificates.
Duplicate the certificate if internal and external VIPs are the same.

Change-Id: I16b345c0b29ff13e042eed8798efe644e0ad2c74
Partially-Implements: blueprint custom-cacerts

commit_message:
Use kolla_toolbox to execute REST methods

Delegate executing uri REST methods to the current module containers
using kolla_toolbox. This will allow self signed certificate that are
already copied into the container to be automatically validated. This
circumvents requiring Kolla Ansible to explicitly disable certificate
validation in the ansible uri module.

Partially-Implements: blueprint custom-cacerts

Change-Id: I2625db7b8000af980e4745734c834c5d9292290b

commit_message:
Add missing auth.tempest_roles

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705007/ moved the standalone stein
jobs to validate-tempest, Few settings related to tempest_roles
got missing leading to barbican tests failure.

Adding it back fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Ie148cad339dbcf16346e21f763dd47cb1f0bec27
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2020-02-06 14:39:07.000000000', 'message': "Remove centos7 job

CentOS7 is a Python 2 based distro, which is now officially not
supported by the current Openstack release.
Despite the efforts made to be able to make the job work with
Python 3, we already have a CentOS8 based job that works natively
with it, so we're removing the CentOS7 job.

Change-Id: Ie48c959c7b31f6676a042e86a018b23d0fdead88
"}]
commit_message:
Remove centos7 job

CentOS7 is a Python 2 based distro, which is now officially not
supported by the current Openstack release.
Despite the efforts made to be able to make the job work with
Python 3, we already have a CentOS8 based job that works natively
with it, so we're removing the CentOS7 job.

Change-Id: Ie48c959c7b31f6676a042e86a018b23d0fdead88

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-28 16:32:23.000000000', 'message': 'Rise async value for containers starting commands

Official documentation states:

If the value of async: is not high enough, this will cause the "check
on it later" task to fail because the temporary status file that the
async_status: is looking for will not have been written or no longer
exist.

And the listed there example has async=1000.

Rize the value of a 300 used in tripleo_container_manage for creating
new containers to appear to be "high enough"...

Change-Id: I598d230bfbb5696f1c0799295d9e456eade56676
Closes-bug: #1861093
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-01-29 08:39:53.000000000', 'message': 'Rise async value for containers starting commands

Official documentation states:

If the value of async: is not high enough, this will cause the "check
on it later" task to fail because the temporary status file that the
async_status: is looking for will not have been written or no longer
exist.

And the listed there example has async=1000.

Rize the value of a 300 used in tripleo_container_manage for creating
new containers to appear to be "high enough"...

Change-Id: I598d230bfbb5696f1c0799295d9e456eade56676
Closes-bug: #1861093
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Rise async value for containers starting commands

Official documentation states:

If the value of async: is not high enough, this will cause the "check
on it later" task to fail because the temporary status file that the
async_status: is looking for will not have been written or no longer
exist.

And the listed there example has async=1000.

Rize the value of a 300 used in tripleo_container_manage for creating
new containers to appear to be "high enough"...

Change-Id: I598d230bfbb5696f1c0799295d9e456eade56676
Closes-bug: #1861093
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

subject: Switch from inspect.getargspec to inspect.getfullargspec
messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-24 12:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-24 12:10:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dan Smith should weigh in on this.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-07 11:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-07 11:49:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Need to add/update a release note'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-07 14:23:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also looks like sets are unordered so the representation isn't stable. Can't remove all of that set formatting code"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-02-07 15:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think that the hashes changing is a real problem, and if we're going to do that, we need to bump the major version of the next release of the library. The hashes are what we use to determine when objects change in incompatible ways in the projects that use this library. It's super uncool to have that change underneath us, so the signaling method needs to be really strong, if we do.

From a quick look, it seems like it should be not too hard to output something equivalent to getargspec when python3-specific features aren't used (like kw-only arguments). I'd like to take a stab at doing something that tries to generate compatible output until it finds a feature that it can't do that for. If you added a kw-only arg to an object method, that would be a hash change anyway, so it would be fine to use the newer argspec output for things using those sorts of features, as long as it's done in just that place."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-02-07 15:01:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also, is there an announced date or version where the old thing will be removed? Or is this just an exercise because we're seeing the deprecation message and feel overly compelled to change everyone's hashes to make that go away?"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-07 15:45:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Also, is there an announced date or version where the old thing
 > will be removed? Or is this just an exercise because we're seeing
 > the deprecation message and feel overly compelled to change
 > everyone's hashes to make that go away?

No, and it's a bit of a mess. fwict, getargspec has been deprecated since 3.0 and getfullargspec, which was introduced in 3.0, was deprecated in 3.5 only for that deprecation to be reversed in 3.6. As such, I'm not sure when this will actually go (it's a similar situation for optparse) but I do think this is something that is more likely to happen now that Python 2.7 is no longer something upstream Python needs to care about. In addition, the next version of o.vo is going to be a major version bump that drops support for Python 2.7 so as far as signaling goes, we can't do much better #SemVer. From the perspective of nova, wouldn't this simply become:

  if oslo_versionedobjects.__version__ >= (2, 0):
      hashes = { ... } # new hashes
  else:
      hashes = { ... } # old hashes

or just update in one go and bump our minimum? The hashes are only for testing purposes, right?"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-07 16:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-24 12:05:47.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Handle deprecation of inspect.getargspec

getargspec has been deprecated in py3 with plans to remove it in a
future release. The recommendation is to move to inspect.signature, but
the results of that call are different than the existing one.

There is also getfullargspec available under py3 that was originally
deprecated, but for the sake of handling 2/3 code, it has been
un-deprecated. This call uses inspect internally, but returns a mostly
compatible result with what getargspec did. This handles getargspec
deprecation by just using getfullargspec instead if it is available

This is WIP because it's breaking the stable hashes we provide via the
'oslo_versionedobjects.fixture.ObjectVersionChecker.get_hashes' method.
We're either going to have to deal with this, via a major version bump
that also drops support for Python 2 or by vendoring the code from
stdlib into o.v.o.

Change-Id: I9d1e9403352e82b0d8721c0efdc856152b9fae86
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-02-07 11:45:55.000000000', 'message': "Switch from inspect.getargspec to inspect.getfullargspec

getargspec has been deprecated in Python 3 with plans to remove it in a
future release. The recommendation is to move to inspect.signature, but
the results of that call are different than the existing one. However,
there is also getfullargspec available under Python 3 that was
originally deprecated but, for the sake of handling 2/3 code, it has
been un-deprecated. This call uses inspect internally, but returns a
mostly compatible result with what getargspec did. This handles
getargspec deprecation by just using getfullargspec instead if it is
available. Switch to using this.

Note that this results in a change in object hashes. This is unavoidable
as the alternative is to vendor the deprecated (and broken, hence its
deprecation) 'getargspec' in o.vo. Since we're dropping Python 2 support
and releasing a new major version, now is as good a time as any to do
this migration.

Change-Id: I9d1e9403352e82b0d8721c0efdc856152b9fae86
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Switch from inspect.getargspec to inspect.getfullargspec

getargspec has been deprecated in Python 3 with plans to remove it in a
future release. The recommendation is to move to inspect.signature, but
the results of that call are different than the existing one. However,
there is also getfullargspec available under Python 3 that was
originally deprecated but, for the sake of handling 2/3 code, it has
been un-deprecated. This call uses inspect internally, but returns a
mostly compatible result with what getargspec did. This handles
getargspec deprecation by just using getfullargspec instead if it is
available. Switch to using this.

Note that this results in a change in object hashes. This is unavoidable
as the alternative is to vendor the deprecated (and broken, hence its
deprecation) 'getargspec' in o.vo. Since we're dropping Python 2 support
and releasing a new major version, now is as good a time as any to do
this migration.

Change-Id: I9d1e9403352e82b0d8721c0efdc856152b9fae86
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
DNM: Add rhel8 support for early CentOS8 testing

RDO is currently using a version of RHEL 8 to test the python3
packaging for the next version of CentOS/RHEL. This change updates
basic support to RHEL8 as a build option.

RHEL8 is used on purpose in order to match RHEL/CentOS 8.

Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/us/956

Change-Id: I3bcef4fbba1f7c59b564446552532ea949bc34c3

commit_message:
Do not append container_name for metal containers

dynamic_inventory.py fails in case of hostname+container_name length
is more than 52 symbols. While it's valid appriach for containers,
it shouldn't raise error when container is deployed on metal, since
nothing will be appended to it's current hostname.

Change-Id: Ifeed116a026042ae32985aaa7ff3f167ef3923f4

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-30 19:06:56.000000000', 'message': 'Octavia: do not attempt container restart on empty list

With composable roles, the node with the octavia agents may not have any
processes running when we hit step 5 external deploy tasks, resulting in
our "one line" restart failing. This patch splits the query for octavia
containers out into a separate task and we conditionally run the restart
task depending on whether there are containers found.

Change-Id: I08a06b300d43aca7db2c9e3341a07bc903163d26
Closes-Bug: #1861413
'}]
commit_message:
Octavia: do not attempt container restart on empty list

With composable roles, the node with the octavia agents may not have any
processes running when we hit step 5 external deploy tasks, resulting in
our "one line" restart failing. This patch splits the query for octavia
containers out into a separate task and we conditionally run the restart
task depending on whether there are containers found.

Change-Id: I08a06b300d43aca7db2c9e3341a07bc903163d26
Closes-Bug: #1861413

commit_message:
Run release-approval job on specific pipeline

Switch the check-release-approval job to run on the new
release-approval pipeline (i.e. on patchset submission, then
on every comment not coming from the zuul user), rather than
on the experimental pipeline (only upon request).

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/706257
Change-Id: I6e0e4e9e7b44947ec5fbc9f638c05a6592d3e139

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-22 21:28:25.000000000', 'message': "Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/catrust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607
"}, {'created': '2020-01-22 21:29:55.000000000', 'message': "Update ro excludes

commit_message:
Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-07 09:42:37.000000000', 'message': "Do not post comments in release-approval pipeline

Since it rus on every (human) comment, the release-approval pipeline
can get pretty noisy. It's also not that critical to read (failure
generally meaning that you don't have the required +1s yet).

This change disables comment posting on success/failure in the pipeline.

Change-Id: I4808a84cd39a5a19ddad86b548ec18d8cadf7430
"}]
commit_message:
Do not post comments in release-approval pipeline

Since it rus on every (human) comment, the release-approval pipeline
can get pretty noisy. It's also not that critical to read (failure
generally meaning that you don't have the required +1s yet).

This change disables comment posting on success/failure in the pipeline.

Change-Id: I4808a84cd39a5a19ddad86b548ec18d8cadf7430

The current role for backup and restore will need service
management to insure that all running services on the nodes
are stopped and restarted in order to capture a consistent state.
This change also includes database dump functionality which will
allow the operator to create a clean backup of the database.

commit_message:
Add service management support.

The current role for backup and restore will need service
management to insure that all running services on the nodes
are stopped and restarted in order to capture a consistent state.
This change also includes database dump functionality which will
allow the operator to create a clean backup of the database.

Change-Id: Ic75f40a750880be4ea00ed79de4575cdbbe0f190

commit_message:
Add Label definition for PTL-Approved

Currently we're just seeing "Allow" in:

  https://review.opendev.org/#/admin/projects/openstack/releases,access

Maybe it's because there is no definition of the label qualities.

Change-Id: I3e7aba14360e4df2e4d7c8f386d3fb9c8b92fa73

commit_message:
Release catellan 2.0.0

This version officially drop the python 2 support so we release a major
version of castellan to inform user that we break
the backward compatibility.

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
-
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ic8cc6d6523089280a0652982161d535184c4e84f

commit_message:
Release automaton 2.0.0

This version officially drop the python 2 support so we release a major
version of automaton to inform user that we break
the backward compatibility.

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
-
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I18f2bcffdaa9d57d5287f1d28d7fce24d3320c3b

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-29 20:28:06.000000000', 'message': 'Improve ssh_known_hosts test coverage

Ensure default test case covers ssh_known_host entries for multiple networks.
Add a second test scenario to cover case where role_networks is not set.

Change-Id: I5c91122b6cbd731d369b19b13fd011114dd48175
Related-bug: #1861296
Related-bug: #1837644
'}, {'created': '2020-01-29 23:14:57.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify ssh_known_hosts role

This is only required for compute nodes running nova_migration_target so
we can simplify the logic significantly.

The host.network entries are now omitted as cold/live migration only uses
either the fqdn,short hostname, or IP. This should help a little with scaling
too as ssh_host_keys can get gigantic with a large number of computes.

We can assume the remaining vars for enabled networks and fqdn/ip are all set
as host vars in the inventory.
Just in case fallback to basic entry when the host vars are missing.

This should also make it easier for operators to run the role in isolation
e.g to quickly fix up the ssh keys on any compute hosts omittied from a
scale-up.

Also fixes bug #1861296 which was caused by attempting to use set to override
a jinja2 var from an outer scope.

Change-Id: I5c91122b6cbd731d369b19b13fd011114dd48175
Closes-bug: #1861296

commit_message:
Simplify ssh_known_hosts role

This is only required for compute nodes running nova_migration_target so
we can simplify the logic significantly.

The host.network entries are now omitted as cold/live migration only uses
either the fqdn,short hostname, or IP. This should help a little with scaling
too as ssh_host_keys can get gigantic with a large number of computes.

We can assume the remaining vars for networks and fqdn/ip are all set as host
or role group vars in the inventory.
Just in case fallback to basic entry when the host vars are missing.

This should also make it easier for operators to run the role in isolation
e.g to quickly fix up the ssh keys on any compute hosts omittied from a
scale-up.

Also fixes bug #1861296 which was caused by attempting to use set to override
a jinja2 var from an outer scope.

Change-Id: I5c91122b6cbd731d369b19b13fd011114dd48175
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/704919/
Closes-bug: #1861296

converage.yaml. Also the lint section isn't necessary because we run
linters seperate.

With more than 4000 lines of code (more than 8000 of unit tests) the

commit_message:
Split cleaning-related functions from manager.py into a new module

With more than 4000 lines of code (more than 8000 of unit tests) the
current manager.py is barely manageable. In preparation for the new
deployment API, this change moves the internal cleaning-related
functions to the new cleaning.py.

Change-Id: I13997af2246327bd11b6aaf7029afb20923e64bc
Story: #2006910

commit_message:
Remove universal wheel configuration

Now that we've dropped py2 support we shouldn't be setting this
anymore.

Change-Id: Iae1a99a9d2644244165b18e030d1c1912ebd98f1

messages:
[{'account_id': 31539, 'date': '2020-01-28 12:55:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2020-01-28 12:55:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Add collectd-pmu package for Intel PMU (C7 only)

The intel_pmu plugin collects performance counters data
on Intel CPUs using Linux perf interface.

C7 only - C8 packaging still pending.

Change-Id: If5044346a90580c4051d6138a84ce10238807460

commit_message:
Allow node owners to administer associated ports

Expose a port's node's owner to policy, giving Ironic admins
the option of modifying the policy file to allow users
specified by a node's owner field to perform API actions on
that node's associated ports.

Change-Id: I47ecbad9729f18dacc703e2a625ef3e92bfb00ed
Story: #2006506
Task: #37539

It seems everything is pluggable now :) I didn't dive into code details, just leaving questions I have here.

1. I guess the locking mechanism is applied to all ironic services, how can we assure that?
2. When we reconfigure the locking mechanism to another one, will the lock state be preserved? And how?"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-28 13:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> It seems everything is pluggable now :) I didn't dive into code
 > details, just leaving questions I have here.
 > 
 > 1. I guess the locking mechanism is applied to all ironic services,
 > how can we assure that?

All inside the conductor. We keep talking about how we should reevaluate all of our locking, but that feels like the phrase "boiling the ocean" as opposed to someone just doing it.

 > 2. When we reconfigure the locking mechanism to another one, will
 > the lock state be preserved? And how?

To change, I think it would be a hard down configuration change. Locks can't live past conductor stop/start (Well, they CAN, but the actual lock holder is no longer doing anything). I'm just not sure there is a clean way to handle upgrades/changes in locking now and in the future.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-10-05 23:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(10 comments)

I feel like we should make get_lock_owner accept task and thus save a database query. I also find it a bit weird to have an abstractmethod with a body. Everything else seems okay, great job with it!'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-06-06 23:29:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> (10 comments)
 > 
 > I feel like we should make get_lock_owner accept task and thus save
 > a database query. I also find it a bit weird to have an
 > abstractmethod with a body. Everything else seems okay, great job
 > with it!

But we can't actually trust OUR task is actually correct if we're a shared task, so we still need to check the database."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-06-07 07:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

We cannot be race-free without an exclusive lock anyway.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-23 22:40:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> We cannot be race-free without an exclusive lock anyway.

I'm unsure of what your point is really trying to get across. I agree with it, except I think the issue is a disagreement in actual operational mechanics.

Going back to the desire to just accepting a task as an argument to skip the need for another lookup. If the task that triggers that lookup is shared, the existing task is not suitable to be used to validate that there are no exclusive locks present, hence the database must be consulted. Upgrade_lock does this presently in changing the field for the lock to exist, returning the latest object.

Example, two worker threads.

Thread one starts with a shared task. No lock is actually generated.
Thread continues to run... Whatever it is doing, say checking current power state.
Thread Two starts after thread one was issued a shared task, but was locked with a task requiring an exclusive lock. That lock is granted because there is no lock recorded on a shared task. 
Thread one determines it needs to upgrade to an exclusive lock. The task it has can't be trusted because it only represents the state in time the thread was launched and the shared task was created, the DB or locking back-end needs to be explicitly consulted because that object will not indicate that the exclusive lock was issued to thread two.

In other words, my perception is that just accepting a task brings risk if we don't reload or query the source of locking truth."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-23 23:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-02 13:04:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> I'm unsure of what your point is really trying to get across.

Hard to remember now, but I think my point was that a shared lock can become invalid (for the lack of a better word) at any point. There is no point to do an additional database lookup, because it can become invalid right after it."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-02 13:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> Thread one determines it needs to upgrade to an exclusive lock. The task it has can't be trusted because it only represents the state in time the thread was launched and the shared task was created, the DB or locking back-end needs to be explicitly consulted because that object will not indicate that the exclusive lock was issued to thread two

Right. Now imagine that thread 2 creates a lock after get_lock_owner is called by thread 1 - same problem with or without an additional database call.

The only solution is to upgrade the lock *first*, then consult the task.node.reservation field (for you need it for). But in this case you don't need a database operation since the node record has been updated on the upgrade."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-02 14:42:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2020-01-02 17:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Build failed. For 3rd party CI contact info: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems

[{'created': '2018-09-01 17:32:55.000000000', 'message': "POC: What would a locking interface look like

So it seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements, that we're
going to have to do something about locking. Seems the
end logical point is to support etcd, but we've wired
database locking on nodes to our core.

Adds locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests.

Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e
"}, {'created': '2018-09-02 00:57:49.000000000', 'message': "POC: What would a locking interface look like

So it seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements, that we're
going to have to do something about locking. Seems the
end logical point is to support etcd, but we've wired
database locking on nodes to our core.

Adds locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present.
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e
"}, {'created': '2018-09-04 03:27:26.000000000', 'message': "POC: What would a locking interface look like

It seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements, that we're
going to have to do something about locking.

Presently we lock all resources associated with a field
on the node object in the conductor. This has some obvious
limitations when it comes to scale and concurrency.

Such as, we can't easily extend to lock more data without
retooling locking as such. We can also only store a single
value at present.

Changing locking, does have major impacts.

We are functionally changing something at the most basic
level of ironic. In some ways we will generate more
database queries with separated locking leveraging the
database.

The advantage though, is that with a delineated interface
we can wire in a distributed lock manager such as etcd.

With that, we can possibly even continue to keep our
current locking model, but levarage more up to date
locking infrmation. Currently we also set ourselves
up for operaiting with out-of-date locking information
by executing a query and then looping upon it expecting
the locking data to be up to date.

Adds locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present.

Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e
"}, {'created': '2018-09-04 23:40:38.000000000', 'message': "Add a locking interface

This started as a proof-of-concept to allow my
brain to focus on some code for a while, but I am
starting to feel more convinced with every revision that
this is the most logical, least negatively impacting path
to take which also allows us a path forward.

It seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements that would be
necessary with the edge use cases that have been discussed
in the ironic communitythat we're going to have to do
something about locking.

Presently we lock all resources associated with a field
on the node object in the conductor. This has some obvious
limitations when it comes to scale and concurrency.

Such as, we can't easily extend to lock more data without
retooling locking as such. We can also only store a single
value at present.

Changing locking, does have major impacts.

We are functionally changing something at the most basic
level of ironic. In some ways we will generate more
database queries with separated locking leveraging the
database, but possibly less queries at the slight cost
an increase of shifting some minor amount of the processing
burden to the conductor from the database (namely, selecting
on the reserve field being populated, and then looping based
on those results, instead of obtaining the results, looping
and querying lock status from that point.

The advantage though, is that with a delineated locking
interface we can wire in a distributed lock manager such
as etcd with fairly minimal headaches.

With that, we can possibly even continue to keep our
current locking model, but levarage more up to date
locking infrmation. Currently we also set ourselves
up for operaiting with out-of-date locking information
by executing a query and then looping upon it expecting
the locking data to be up to date.

Adds a locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces, ands tests to verify basic behavior.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests that can skew such observations.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present
in every single case.

Story: #1526751
Task: #10387
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e

something about locking.

Presently we lock all resources associated with a field
on the node object in the conductor. This has some obvious
limitations when it comes to scale and concurrency.

Such as, we can't easily extend to lock more data without
retooling locking as such. We can also only store a single
value at present.

Changing locking, does have major impacts.

We are functionally changing something at the most basic
level of ironic. In some ways we will generate more
database queries with separated locking leveraging the
database, but possibly less queries at the slight cost
an increase of shifting some minor amount of the processing
burden to the conductor from the database (namely, selecting
on the reserve field being populated, and then looping based
on those results, instead of obtaining the results, looping
and querying lock status from that point.

The advantage though, is that with a delineated locking
interface we can wire in a distributed lock manager such
as etcd with fairly minimal headaches.

With that, we can possibly even continue to keep our
current locking model, but levarage more up to date
locking infrmation. Currently we also set ourselves
up for operaiting with out-of-date locking information
by executing a query and then looping upon it expecting
the locking data to be up to date.

Adds a locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces, ands tests to verify basic behavior.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests that can skew such observations.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present
in every single case.

Story: #1526751
Task: #10387
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests that can skew such observations.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present
in every single case.

Story: #1526751
Task: #10387
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e
"}, {'created': '2019-05-28 12:09:58.000000000', 'message': "Add a locking interface

This started as a proof-of-concept to allow my
brain to focus on some code for a while, but I am
starting to feel more convinced with every revision that
this is the most logical, least negatively impacting path
to take which also allows us a path forward.

It seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements that would be
necessary with the edge use cases that have been discussed
in the ironic community that we're going to have to do
something about locking.

Presently we lock all resources associated with a field
on the node object in the conductor. This has some obvious
limitations when it comes to scale and concurrency.

Such as, we can't easily extend to lock more data without
retooling locking as such. We can also only store a single
value at present.

Changing locking, does have major impacts.

We are functionally changing something at the most basic
level of ironic. In some ways we will generate more
database queries with separated locking leveraging the
database, but possibly less queries at the slight cost
an increase of shifting some minor amount of the processing
burden to the conductor from the database (namely, selecting
on the reserve field being populated, and then looping based
on those results, instead of obtaining the results, looping
and querying lock status from that point.

The advantage though, is that with a delineated locking
interface we can wire in a distributed lock manager such
as etcd with fairly minimal headaches.

With that, we can possibly even continue to keep our
current locking model, but levarage more up to date
locking information. Currently we also set ourselves
up for operating with out-of-date locking information
by executing a query and then looping upon it expecting
the locking data to be up to date.

Adds a locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces, ands tests to verify basic behavior.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests that can skew such observations.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present
in every single case.

Story: #1526751
Task: #10387
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e

commit_message:
Add a locking interface

This started as a proof-of-concept to allow my
brain to focus on some code for a while, but I am
starting to feel more convinced with every revision that
this is the most logical, least negatively impacting path
to take which also allows us a path forward.

It seems clear with many of the discussions about
parallelism and performance improvements that would be
necessary with the edge use cases that have been discussed
in the ironic community that we're going to have to do
something about locking.

Presently we lock all resources associated with a field
on the node object in the conductor. This has some obvious
limitations when it comes to scale and concurrency.

Such as, we can't easily extend to lock more data without
retooling locking as such. We can also only store a single
value at present.

Changing locking, does have major impacts.

We are functionally changing something at the most basic
level of ironic. In some ways we will generate more
database queries with separated locking leveraging the
database, but possibly less queries at the slight cost
an increase of shifting some minor amount of the processing
burden to the conductor from the database (namely, selecting
on the reserve field being populated, and then looping based
on those results, instead of obtaining the results, looping
and querying lock status from that point.

The advantage though, is that with a delineated locking
interface we can wire in a distributed lock manager such
as etcd with fairly minimal headaches.

With that, we can possibly even continue to keep our
current locking model, but levarage more up to date
locking information. Currently we also set ourselves
up for operating with out-of-date locking information
by executing a query and then looping upon it expecting
the locking data to be up to date.

Adds a locking interface, with a single driver module
to be loaded that wraps the calls to the database.
Minimally tests that we behave as expected with different
interfaces, ands tests to verify basic behavior.

Unit test times, on a laptop with thermal throttling,
do not seem to have any observable change, although
the SNMP and Redfish tests have some long running
tests that can skew such observations.

Also removes a number of database query filters on
periodic tasks that excluded nodes that were presently
locked from being picked up by the periodic tasks. Code
to handle lock allocation failures was already present
in every single case.

Story: #1526751
Task: #10387
Change-Id: I5c02f994552278526c202d04ce1e99b21f63122e

commit_message:
Remove hardcoding of python interpreter for rhel8

Let ansible do its autodiscovery then hardcoding interpreter,
it will allow to run quickstart.sh on virthosts of mixed py2/py3
environments.
Change-Id: I528bf9a10622c9ea3c2898c6b714eb9fb29a79cb

commit_message:
Split deployment-related functions from manager.py into a new module

With more than 4000 lines of code (more than 8000 of unit tests) the
current manager.py is barely manageable. In preparation for the new
deployment API, this change moves the free-standing deploy-related
functions to utils.py and the new deployments.py.

Change-Id: Ic3f369a7fa72d09263b0670ae78980913b024962
Story: #2006910

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Remove cruft from setup.cfg.

'}, {'created': '2020-01-30 15:34:34.000000000', 'message': 'Remove wait when retrieving OVS dp

OVS agent is a single thread module executed on a os-ken AppManager
context. os-ken uses, by default (and no other implementation is
available today [1]), "eventlet" threads. Those threads are scheduled
manually by the code itself; the context switch is done through
yielding. The easiest way to do this is by executing:
  eventlet.sleep()

If the assigned thread is not ready to take the GIL and do not yield
back the executor, other threads will starve and eventually will
timeout.

This patch removes the "sleep" command during the DP retrieval. This
will keep the executor on the current thread and will prevent the
execution timeouts, as seen in the bug related.

[1]https://opendev.org/openstack/os-ken/src/commit/1f751b2d7d385a75d4255934694177d6fd6f012f/os_ken/lib/hub.py

Closes-Bug: #1861269

Change-Id: I19e1af1bda788ed970d30ab251e895f7daa11e39
'}, {'created': '2020-01-30 15:35:06.000000000', 'message': 'Remove sleep command when retrieving OVS dp

  eventlet.sleep()

If the assigned thread is not ready to take the GIL and do not yield
back the executor, other threads will starve and eventually will
timeout.

This patch removes the "sleep" command during the DP retrieval. This
will keep the executor on the current thread and will prevent the
execution timeouts, as seen in the bug related.

[1]https://opendev.org/openstack/os-ken/src/commit/1f751b2d7d385a75d4255934694177d6fd6f012f/os_ken/lib/hub.py

Change-Id: I19e1af1bda788ed970d30ab251e895f7daa11e39
'}]
commit_message:
Remove sleep command when retrieving OVS dp

OVS agent is a single thread module executed on a os-ken AppManager
context. os-ken uses, by default (and no other implementation is
available today [1]), "eventlet" threads. Those threads are scheduled
manually by the code itself; the context switch is done through
yielding. The easiest way to do this is by executing:
  eventlet.sleep()

If the assigned thread is not ready to take the GIL and do not yield
back the executor, other threads will starve and eventually will
timeout.

This patch removes the "sleep" command during the DP retrieval. This
will keep the executor on the current thread and will prevent the
execution timeouts, as seen in the bug related.

[1]https://opendev.org/openstack/os-ken/src/commit/1f751b2d7d385a75d4255934694177d6fd6f012f/os_ken/lib/hub.py

Closes-Bug: #1861269

Change-Id: I19e1af1bda788ed970d30ab251e895f7daa11e39

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

theme now.

[{'created': '2019-12-05 09:31:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix the Octavia amphora provider driver description

octavia_tempest_plugin.tests.api.v2.test_provider.ProviderAPITest.test_provider_list
fails with the following:

testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: 'The Octavia Amphora driver.' != 'Octavia Amphora Driver.'

Change-Id: I37245f6cada11f060b8a0b8da06a583d64bb347b
(cherry picked from commit 88d6c029db2aa0d7ae8106f7add5d88b8562e61b)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the Octavia amphora provider driver description

octavia_tempest_plugin.tests.api.v2.test_provider.ProviderAPITest.test_provider_list
fails with the following:

testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: 'The Octavia Amphora driver.' != 'Octavia Amphora Driver.'

Change-Id: I37245f6cada11f060b8a0b8da06a583d64bb347b
(cherry picked from commit 88d6c029db2aa0d7ae8106f7add5d88b8562e61b)

'}, {'created': '2020-02-06 00:13:11.000000000', 'message': 'Use stable constraint in run-tempest for stable branch testing

Stable branches till stable/rocky is using python
version <py3.6. Tempest test those branch in venv
but Tempest tox use the master upper-constraint[1]
which block installation due to dependencies
require >=py3.6. For exmaple, oslo.concurrency 4.0.0
is not compatible for <py3.6.

As we pin Tempest for EM stable brach, we should be
able to use stable constraint for Tempest installation
as well as while running during run-tempest playbook.

tox.ini is hard coded to use master constraint[1] which force
run-tempest to recreate the tox env and use the master constraint.

Devstack can set stable u-c to use via env var but this is
not enough as Tempest role run-tempest recreate the tox
env with master u-c.
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705089/4/lib/tempest

Currently we are fixing run-tempest to use stable constraint
till stable/rocky which use distro having <py3.6.

Ideally, we can change compatible branch constraint in tox.ini
while doing release tag for Tempest. But that can be done
for future tags only.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/bc9fe8eca801f54915ff3eafa418e6e18ac2df63/tox.ini#L14

Change-Id: I4268049ff91e5527e4b95fd8a70fa53ba27d56ed

Change-Id: I4268049ff91e5527e4b95fd8a70fa53ba27d56ed
'}]
commit_message:
Use stable constraint in run-tempest for stable branch testing

Stable branches till stable/rocky is using python
version <py3.6. Tempest test those branch in venv
but Tempest tox use the master upper-constraint[1]
which block installation due to dependencies
require >=py3.6. For exmaple, oslo.concurrency 4.0.0
is not compatible for <py3.6.

As we pin Tempest for EM stable brach, we should be
able to use stable constraint for Tempest installation
as well as while running during run-tempest playbook.

tox.ini is hard coded to use master constraint[1] which force
run-tempest to recreate the tox env and use the master constraint.

Devstack can set stable u-c to use via env var but this is
not enough as Tempest role run-tempest recreate the tox
env with master u-c.
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705089/4/lib/tempest

Currently we are fixing run-tempest to use stable constraint
till stable/rocky which use distro having <py3.6.

Ideally, we can change compatible branch constraint in tox.ini
while doing release tag for Tempest. But that can be done
for future tags only.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/bc9fe8eca801f54915ff3eafa418e6e18ac2df63/tox.ini#L14

Change-Id: I4268049ff91e5527e4b95fd8a70fa53ba27d56ed

commit_message:
Add support for swift-recon-cron job

Add support to configure swift-recon-cron job, which is
required to have object async pendings shown in recon API.

Change-Id: Iae3705db38ebaddf92ee6e80c20c1011f8f66706

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

specs repo either has py27 job or requirement or tox env.

Add bindep.txt file so that wheels can be build.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I51c3bcf161b363e4b188175b75097d19a0d10a74

This [0] lets me create an extra vars file [1] and this [2] configures the shell script to run it [3].

The problem is that the extra vars files contains THT, not vars that ceph-ansible will know what to do with so I need to update tripleo-ansible's tripleo-ceph-work-dir/tasks/prepare.yml or modify how this works to directly support ceph-ansible's vars, not THT vars. I'll try that in the next PS. Since it's a new param there may not be much value in having a translation layer from THT to ceph-ansible here.

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud multiceph]$'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-13 16:38:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-13 16:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-13 19:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

From the deploy artifacts [0] I see:

- the desired extra_vars [1]
- the desired run  ceph_ansible_command.sh [2]
- the desired fsid in the /etc/ceph/ceph2.conf [3][4]

The reason the deployment failed [5] is expected because the 
validation which tried to vierf was tryint to verify its 
connection to the external ceph cluster [6]. 

Maybe the CI job could be updated to run that validation for 
the first ceph cluster (the internal one) but not the exernal
one.

One problem I see is that /etc/ceph/ is missing [3] the file 
ceph2.client.openstack.keyring.gz. The ceph.client.openstack.keyring.gz
looks correct however [7]; it was not badly affected by the change and
has the expected key (from CephClientKey and not CephMultiBackendsHash).

Next step: Why is /etc/ceph/ceph2.client.openstack.keyring missing?

[0] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_ece/702141/3/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario001-standalone/ecefb48/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/standalone-ansible-KMkjf5/ceph-ansible/

[1] 
[fultonj@runcible down]$ cat extra_vars_ceph2.yml.txt 
cluster: ceph2
external_cluster_mon_ips: 192.168.24.251
fsid: e2cba068-5f14-4b0f-b047-acf375c0004a
openstack_keys:
-   caps:
        mgr: allow *
        mon: profile rbd

the new code and is green. We also see that it produced the desired
results because it configured both an internal ceph cluster (as usual)

see that the desired files were created so that you could connect to
it in /etc/ceph [0] (ceph2.conf, ceph2.client.openstack.keyring [1]).

As per the config-download/ceph-ansible directory [2] we see that 
inventory-external.ini and extra_vars_ceph2.yml were created and
that the ceph_ansible_command.sh was updated to do a second run
but using these new parameter files.

The RDO failure is from tripleo-ci-rhel-8-scenario001-standalone-rdo and it failed as a result of this change:

http://logs.rdoproject.org/41/702141/10/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-rhel-8-scenario001-standalone-rdo/e5ae85c/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/ansible.log

It ran the first external playbook fine and then failed [1] here: 

/usr/share/ceph-ansible/infrastructure-playbooks/dashboard.yml': line 70, column 3

because of this:

hosts: "{{ groups[mgr_group_name] | default(groups[mon_group_name]) }}"

The reason for that is that the second execution doesn't have mons defined.  Even if we made ceph-ansible handle this with another default if there are no mons (and there are none in the second execution by design), the problem is that it's trying to deploy the dashboard. In this THT submission I updated the parameters 001 so it would run the second deployment:

 ci/environments/scenario001-standalone.yaml

but I left other scenario004 alone and it's green so that would prove that introducing this change doesn't break anything. The artifacts of the RDO job show that it is using the above paramters as it did create the extra vars:

http://logs.rdoproject.org/41/702141/10/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-rhel-8-scenario001-standalone-rdo/e5ae85c/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/standalone-ansible-sp2bxjev/ceph-ansible/ceph2_external_extra_vars.yml

As the above has "dashboard_enabled: false" I would think it should not attempt to run the infrastructure-playbooks/dashboard.yml playbook. So why did it?

[1]
Running /home/zuul/standalone-ansible-sp2bxjev/ceph-ansible/ceph2_external_ceph_ansible_command.sh
...
020-01-26 04:12:20,071 p=76359 u=root |  PLAY [grafana-server] **********************************************************
2020-01-26 04:12:20,072 p=76359 u=root |  skipping: no hosts matched
2020-01-26 04:12:20,081 p=76359 u=root |  ERROR! The field 'hosts' has an invalid value, which includes an undefined variable. The error was: 'dict object' has no attribute 'mons'

The error appears to be in '/usr/share/ceph-ansible/infrastructure-playbooks/dashboard.yml': line 70, column 3, but may
be elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.

The offending line appears to be:


- hosts: "{{ groups[mgr_group_name] | default(groups[mon_group_name]) }}"
  ^ here
We could be wrong, but this one looks like it might be an issue with
missing quotes. Always quote template expression brackets when they
start a value. For instance:

    with_items:
      - {{ foo }}

Should be written as:

    with_items:
      - "{{ foo }}"

Introduce CephExternalMultiConfig

Add new parameter which may be used to configure an
overcloud to use more than one external Ceph cluster.

Implements: blueprint multiple-external-ceph

[{'created': '2019-11-08 11:40:52.000000000', 'message': "Fix c_facts in needs_delete() filter

Later in the filter, we compare the config_data, but c_facts had the
container name in the key, which we don't need during the compare.
Use json to manipulate the dictionary and construct something that will

Change-Id: I3103f642ba86111e02d06922876b5f1ac78df602
"}, {'created': '2019-11-08 12:39:53.000000000', 'message': "Fix idempotency in needs_delete

Fix c_facts in needs_delete() filter
Later in the filter, we compare the config_data, but c_facts had the
container name in the key, which we don't need during the compare.
Use json to manipulate the dictionary and construct something that will
be compared to the config_data.

Also don't remove the container when all these conditions are met:
- a container is part of the config_id
- a container is running
- this container isn't in the tripleo_container_manage_config path.
The reason is, we'll let operators to deploy containers individually, so
we don't want to touch other containers not in the config at that time.

Change-Id: I3103f642ba86111e02d06922876b5f1ac78df602
"}, {'created': '2019-11-08 13:30:14.000000000', 'message': "Relax needs_delete() filter

Don't remove a container when all these conditions are met:
- the container is part of the config_id
- the container is running
- the container isn't in the tripleo_container_manage_config path.

The reason is, we'll let operators to deploy containers individually, so
we don't want to touch other containers not in the config at that time.

Example: as an operator I want to apply ansible on haproxy
(config_step1); so I don't want other containers from config_step1 to be
removed.

This code was here to cleanup containers not part of the config (e.g. if
you upgrade and a container isn't used anymore); but it's too agressive.
If a container isn't needed anymore, it'll need to be handled during the
upgrade steps.

Change-Id: I3103f642ba86111e02d06922876b5f1ac78df602
"}]
commit_message:
Relax needs_delete() filter

Don't remove a container when all these conditions are met:
- the container is part of the config_id
- the container is running
- the container isn't in the tripleo_container_manage_config path.

The reason is, we'll let operators to deploy containers individually, so
we don't want to touch other containers not in the config at that time.

Example: as an operator I want to apply ansible on haproxy
(config_step1); so I don't want other containers from config_step1 to be
removed.

This code was here to cleanup containers not part of the config (e.g. if
you upgrade and a container isn't used anymore); but it's too agressive.
If a container isn't needed anymore, it'll need to be handled during the
upgrade steps.

Change-Id: I3103f642ba86111e02d06922876b5f1ac78df602

commit_message:
tripleo-container-manage: allow to override a container config

Sometimes an operator might want to override a config parameter for a
specific container, without having to rewrite the JSON on the host.

It can now be done with the new
tripleo_container_manage_config_overrides parameter.

Example:

tripleo_container_manage_config_override:
  mysql:
    image: myregistry.io/tripleomaster/haproxy:latest

It introduces a new attribute to the singledict() filter and its unit
test.

Change-Id: If65fcf25c9e07174b08e44539b0501615b6c72ab

commit_message:
Disable stable/rocky temporarily on Tempest master

Stable/rocky jobs are broken due to py2
drop by Tempest dependency.
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-February/012371.html

Fixes are on devstack stable/rocky and tempest side
- https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:fix-stable-gate+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

To get the Tempest fix and other patches merged
we need to disable the rocky jobs on master gate
temporary and bring them back once everything is fixed.

Tempest fix blocked due to stable/rocky jobs
-https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705870/

Change-Id: I2238387c42650aceb9bacf51a4116ce6887cc460

[{'created': '2020-02-05 16:56:11.000000000', 'message': 'Pass only variables starting with ANSIBLE

When config-download runs ceph-ansible it does so by calling
Ansible from within Ansible. We all ANSIBLE_* environment
variables to the nested Ansible execution. However there was
a bug where any variable containing ANSILBE was included, not
just those starting with ANSIBLE. This fix ensures we filter
out only variables starting with ANSIBLE.

Change-Id: I9f3e18dcf520ee7ac6370a49d0ae003a192d9bd3
Closes-Bug: 1862031
'}]
commit_message:
Pass only variables starting with ANSIBLE

When config-download runs ceph-ansible it does so by calling
Ansible from within Ansible. We all ANSIBLE_* environment
variables to the nested Ansible execution. However there was
a bug where any variable containing ANSILBE was included, not
just those starting with ANSIBLE. This fix ensures we filter
out only variables starting with ANSIBLE.

Change-Id: I9f3e18dcf520ee7ac6370a49d0ae003a192d9bd3
Closes-Bug: 1862031

commit_message:
Improve idempotency of podman_container

Make image comparing more readable
If 'command' is not set, don't compare it with current,
assume it's empty.

Change-Id: I935c617b242fb955ed08ed492bbd09e7f3f4fd4c
(cherry picked from commit fe6d3d4721b76ee13e2950af0f522ede3d530a7f)

commit_message:
Intel Node Manager sensor collection support

This spec propose support for collecting sensor information from Intel
Node Manager for Ironic.

Change-Id: I5fb57a8fd27209157563cb7dfa194ac160892ec9
Related-bug: #1645759

commit_message:
Convert get_config to a direct call instead of using mistral

This change uses the the generated mistral context to call the underlying workflow
function without needing mistral.

Story: 2007212
Task: 38436

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706196/
Change-Id: I79ded325b904bf0f60408250611935d229eda426
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make aggregates/availability zones support ironic nodes

This spec describes how to make AZ or aggregates support ironic node.
Ironic nodes can be add/remove to/remove from AZ or aggregates. It's
helpful for administrators to organize baremetal nodes. F.g. some
baremetals in DMZ is an independent AZ. Others in core production
zone is another AZ.

Change-Id: Ie7b59124764c95e501c42895cb36a8c585e566c4
Related-Bug: #1661571

commit_message:
Remove Mistral from plan list and call the Mistral action directly

This change creates a context that mimics the Mistral context. This
allows us to short-circuit and cut Mistral out, calling the Python
action directly.

All plan list actions have been updated to use this new process and
the old mistral function has been deleted.

Story: 2007247
Task: 38594

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706196/
Change-Id: I463b5e3d1c4c15dd859a841d65a5057716f84208

commit_message:
Generic way to configure clean step priorites in Automated cleaning

This Specification allows generic way of configuring the clean step
priorities instead of adding changes in Ironic for each clean step
being introduced.

Related-bug: #1618014
Change-Id: I69959d15da549eee556fbf3bbeaf13ea7662b6d4

this is fine as-is.

However, keep in mind, this is the sort of thing we could just put directly into tripleoclient, with no need to use ansible. There is already code in tripleoclient to get a stack output in utils.py, get_stack_output_item.

Just because there was a mistral workbook previously, does not mean we must create a 1:1 mapping of an ansible playbook. This is an opportunity to simplify, and I actually think in this case an ansible playbook for getting the horizon url is overkill. Especially since the point of that playbook is just to call back into openstack client.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-01-31 23:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Convert horizon url workflow to ansible

This change will now use an ansible playbook to parse the horizon URL
information from a heat stack and return the connection string
accordingly.

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-22 22:57:32.000000000', 'message': "Convert deployment to use new ssh-admin playbook

This change converts the deployment process to use the new enable ssh admin
playbook. The admin and deploy workflows have been recreated in the v2
directory and updated to match the new method parameters. Utils was also
updated to use a couple new ssh arguments that are both useful and were
being used in the ssh shell commands we were running in the original
deployment workflow.

Tests have been updated to reflect the use of the new methods. Not all
workflows have been placed into the v2 directory, only the ones that
have argument changes have been moved over. While not everything touched
is moved over to v2, all workflows that used the `` deployment function
have been updated to use the new function arguments. This will ensure
we're not breaking compatibility with the legacy api.

Change-Id: I5c744e116f00e81f92c014fc1f599ad3db11ada2
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Convert deployment to use new ssh-admin playbook

This change converts the deployment process to use the new enable ssh admin
playbook instead of the shell commands and a mistral workflow.

Tests have been updated to reflect the use of the new methods.

Story: 2007212
Task: 38427
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706196/
Depends-On: I5ab7f4d9dc39a74714c9bcfa39fa50cc586e8e08
Change-Id: I5c744e116f00e81f92c014fc1f599ad3db11ada2
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Extend the mistral context class

This change extends our mistral context class to ensure that we're passing everything that
tripleo-common will expect, which includes deprecated objects.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706196/
Change-Id: I9dae28d597be0d11acaa35026f5316db4d6d8ae1
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13295, 'date': '2017-02-27 15:18:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Hey Yuriy & Joanna,

Please see the notes starting from L330 here: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ironic-pike-ptg-future-work

Like Vlad mentioned, the general consensus was that the burden this feature might add in terms of complexity, testing, and documentation upkeep wasn't worth the benefit of fixing console-related bugs for only 1 type of ironic deployment.

Instead, two work items were proposed to mitigate the concerns in this spec:

1. Kubernetes support can be implemented in a new console driver, instead of introducing a whole new framework into ironic.

2. https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1632192 can be fixed via an alternative strategy that forces the console process to die when the parent (conductor) process dies. TheJulia has started looking into this.

In the future, if the work to mitigate console errors turns out to be too difficult and ironic deployment on K8s is more widely used, then we can revisit this.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-02-07 01:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning spec as it has not been updated in nearly three years. If there is interest in it at a later time, it can be resurrected.'}]

commit_message:
Internal API for long running tasks

This specs proposes adding new internal API for long running
tasks.

Related-bug: #1632192
Change-Id: Ie75e38659382334a21d69d9d432cc5d28962b1f1
